column55: only 6.6%(158/2403) of high-risk women obtained breast MRI screening within a 2-yearwindow of their screening mammogram. Patient factors associated with on-site MRIscreening use included younger (<40 years) age (odds ratio [OR] = 2.39
column62: 95% CI: 1.04-4.74).CONCLUSIONS: While nearly half of women at high lifetime breast cancer riskundergo routine screening mammography at a facility with on-site breast MRIavailability

Future studies should evaluatewhether other enabling factors such as formal risk assessment and patientawareness of high lifetime breast cancer risk can mitigate the underutilizationof supplemental screening breast MRI.

column37: adjusting for woman and tumor characteristics.RESULTS: Overall
column38: preoperative MRI use was 16.4%. The proportion of womenreceiving breast MRI was similar by breast density (17.6% dense

column40: 16.5% without family history).After adjusting for potential confounders

column42: 95% CI: 0.73-1.22)or family history (OR = 0.99 for family history vs. none

column8: U.S.A.^PURPOSE: Seminomas are solid tumors in young men
column9: but which rarely metastasize tothe orbit. The authors review the known literature on seminoma metastatic to theorbit
column10: and describe an additional case in a 33-year-old man.METHODS: A literature search was performed on the MEDLINE database using keywords"seminoma
column15: and germ-cell neoplasms."RESULTS: Malignant neoplasms of the testis account for only 1% of cancers in men.None-the-less
column16: testicular germ cell seminoma is the most common solid tumor foundin young men between the ages of 15 and 39. Only seven previous cases have beenmentioned in the literature. The pathogenesis remains unclear although genetic
column18: and maternal factors may play a role. The number of cases is toofew to determine the best treatment options
column19: but surgical excision and adjunctiveorbital radiotherapy appear to be most appropriate.CONCLUSIONS: Although metastases to the orbit are rare
column20: seminoma should beconsidered in the differential diagnosis of all young men with proptosis.

The odds ratio (OR) forbreast cancer in the top vs. bottom quartile of AMH was 1.60 (95%CI = 1.31-1.94). Though the test for interaction was not statisticallysignificant (pinteraction  = 0.15)

column1: Med Sci Sports Exerc. 2018 Jun;50(6):1169-1176. doi:10.1249/MSS.0000000000001544.^Exercise Protects against Cancer-induced Cardiac Cachexia.^Parry TL(1)

column5: NC.(2)School of Sport and Exercise Science

column9: CO.^Cancer has been shown to negatively stimulate autophagy
column10: leading to a decline incardiac function. Although exercise is cardioprotective
column11: its influence overautophagy-mediated tumor growth and cardiac function are not welldefined.PURPOSE: This study aimed to determine the effect of exercise on tumormorphology and cardiac function.METHODS: Fisher 344 rats (n = 28) were assigned to one of four groups: 1)sedentary non-tumor bearing (SED)
column14: or 4) wheel run tumor bearing (WR + T). Rats remainedsedentary or exercised for 6 wk. At week 4
column15: rats in tumor groups were inoculatedwith MatBIII tumor cells. At week 6
column16: cardiac function was measured.RESULTS: SED + T animals exhibited significantly lower left ventricular developedpressure when compared with SED
column18: and WR + T (P < 0.05). This coincided with asignificant increase in cardiac autophagy (increased LC3-II) in SED + T animalswhen compared with SED
column21: SED + T heartsshowed a significant increase in β-myosin heavy chain expression versus nontumorgroups (P < 0.05). Tumor mass was significantly larger (P < 0.001) in SED + Tanimals when compared with WR + T animals
column22: which was accompanied by a significantincrease in tumor LC3-II protein expression (P < 0.05).CONCLUSION: Nonexercised tumor-bearing rats showed severe cardiac dysfunction andexcessive
column23: maladaptive autophagy in the heart and tumors. Voluntary exercisepreserved cardiac function and attenuated the autophagic response in heart andtumor tissues. This preservation may be related to the reduced tumor growth inaerobically exercised rats
column24: to the improved regulation of autophagy by exercise
